intro.description:
This cheat sheet guides you through the steps to create a Project containing a test which you can execute.
The application to be tested is a small calculator in which we can enter two numbers, click an "add" button, and see the result.

item.title: Create a Project
item.description: The following steps show you how to create a Project.

subitem.label: Select: Project > New
Enter "SimpleAdder" as the Project Name
Choose "concrete" as the toolkit
Choose "English (United States) as the Project language
Click "Next"

item.title: Define and configure an AUT
item.description: The next steps show you how to add an AUT to your Project and how to configure it so that GUIdancer can start it.

subitem.label: Enter "Adder" as the AUT name
Choose "Swing" as the toolkit, because the AUT has a Swing GUI.
Click "Next"
Select which AUT Starter to use. (Localhost is the default setting)
Enter the jar file name: â€C:\Program Files\GUIdancer\aut\adder\adder.jar"
Click "Finish"

item.title: Import the Test Case library
item.description: The next steps show you how to import the installed library of Test Cases.

subitem.label: Select: Project > Import
Browse to: "guidancer/aut/testCaseLibrary"
Select "unbound_modules_concrete_<versionnumber>.xml"
Click OK in the file chooser

item.title: Add the Test Case library to the Project
item.description: The next steps show you how to reuse the imported Test Case library in your Project to make test creation easier and more structured.

subitem.label: Select: Project > Settings
Select "Used Projects"
Select the highest version of "unbound_modules_concrete.xml"
Click the right arrow to reuse this Project in the currently opened Project
Click OK
The reused library of Test Cases appears in the Test Case Browser. It is grayed out because it is a reused Project and cannot be edited here.

item.title: Create a Test Case
item.description:
Now you will create a Test Case to make the program perform an addition and check the result.
Test Cases are reusable modules.
Note that the following steps are all completed based on the requirements for the AUT - we are not dependent on the AUT to create tests.

subitem.label: In the Test Case Browser, right-click on the "Test Cases" node and select: New > Test Case from the context-sensitive menu
Enter "PerformAddition" as the Test Case name.
Click OK
The Test Case you created appears in the Test Case Browser.

item.title: Create a Test Step
item.description: Test Steps are the smallest unit in GUIdancer. A Test Step consists of three pieces of information: the graphical component to be tested, the action to perform on the component, and the data that the action needs.

subitem.label: Double-click on the Test Case you just created to open the Test Case Editor
In the Test Case Editor, right click on the Test Case and select: Add > New Test Step
Enter "Enter value one" as the Test Step name

Select "Component with Text Input" as the component. The first thing we want the test to do is to enter a value into a field in the program. "Component with Text Input" covers all possibilities for components we can enter text into.
Enter "adder_value1" as the component name. A component name is the tester's name for a graphical component. It is used later to map the test specification to the actual AUT.
Select "Replace Text" as the action. This action will perform 3 clicks in the field and then enter the text value specified.
Click OK
The Test Step appears underneath the Test Case in the editor

In the Properties View, enter "=VALUE1" (without the quotes) into the "parameter" field and press enter. This is a reference. The parameter value will be entered later. You can see the referenced parameter next to the Test Case in the editor. This makes the Test Case more reusable.
Save the editor

item.title: Add reused Test Cases
item.description: Test Step creation is one way of creating tests. However, GUIdancer's strength is in reusability. To help with this, you can use the library of reused Test Cases we imported.

subitem.label: In the Test Case Browser, open the category: basic > Component with Text Input > Replace Text
Drag the Test Case that is in this category and drop it into the Test Case Editor, underneath the Test Step you just created.
In the Properties View, enter "=VALUE2" into the "parameter field" and press enter.

In the Component Names View, enter "adder_value2" in the "new name" field. This is because the library of Test Cases all have very general component names. To make object mapping easier later, it is better to have meaningful component names.
In the Test Case Browser, open the category: basic > graphics component > Click
Drag the "ub_grc_click" Test Case into the Test Case Editor.
Enter "1" as the click count and "1" as the mouse button (1 is the left mouse button).
In the Component Names View, enter "equalsButton" in the "new name" field.
In the Test Case Browser, open the category: basic > component with text > check text
Drag the "ub_ct_checkText" Test Case into the Test Case Editor.
In the Properties View, enter "=RESULT" and press enter.
In the Component Names View, enter "resultField" in the "new name" field.
Save the editor.
You now have a Test Case which will enter any two values into two fields, click the "add" button and check the result.

item.title: Add data
item.description: Now that the test specification is ready, data can be added to the Test Case.

subitem.label: In the Test Case Editor, click on the "PerformAddition" Test Case.

In the Data Sets View, enter "1" under the VALUE1 heading. Enter "2" under the VALUE2 heading. And enter "3" under the RESULT heading. This creates one data set which tests that the value "3" is given when "1" and "2" are added.
In the Data Sets View, click "Add" and enter another set of data to test (e.g. 5,6,11)
Save the editor.

item.title: Create a Test Suite
item.description: Test Suites are the executable units in GUIdancer.

subitem.label: In the Test Suite Browser, right click and select: New > Test Suite from the context-sensitive menu.
Enter "TestAdder" as the Test Suite name.
Click OK.
Double click on the Test Suite you just created.
Drag the "PerformAddition" Test Case from the Test Case Browser into the Test Suite Browser.
Save the editor.

item.title: Object mapping
item.description:
Now the test is almost ready. The specification is done, and data have been added. The last step is to join the specification with the actual AUT.
This step is called object mapping, and it is the first time that the AUT is required.

subitem.label: Start the AUT Starter via the start menu.
Connect to the AUT Starter using the toolbar button.
Start the AUT using the toolbar button.
In the Test Suite Editor, right click on the Test Suite and select: open with > object mapping editor.
In the object mapping editor, you can see all the component names you used in this Test Suite.
Start the object mapping mode using the toolbar button.
Switch to the AUT.
Hover over the top text field. It will have a green border. Press Ctrl+Shift+A to "collect" the component.
Check in the object mapping editor that this component (technical name) has been collected.
In the AUT, collect the second text field in the same way. Then collect the equals button and the result field.
In the object mapping editor, take the technical name for the first text field and drag it onto your component name for the first text field (adder_value1).
Repeat this process for the other technical names. In this way, you tell GUIdancer which components to test in your specification.
Stop the object mapping mode using the toolbar button.
Save the editor.

item.title: Execute the test
item.description:
The test is now ready to be executed.
Because this test will run locally, do not move the mouse during the test.

subitem.label: Start the Test Suite using the button on the toolbar.
In the dialog, choose to switch to the execution perspective.
Wait for the test to end.
